artworkTitle: Prehistoric Art depicted in Cubism Art Style

keySubjects: Cave walls or rocky landscape elements (as subject matter)
conceptDefinition.narrativeFocus: Depict a group of simplified, active human figures engaged in hunting a large bison or similar prehistoric animal. Focus on the action and relationship between hunters and prey.
conceptDefinition.desiredEmotion: A mix of ritualistic reverence, primal tension, and the importance of the hunt for survival.
symbolismHints: Emphasize the size and power of the animal
Use repetitive patterns if suggesting ritual
references: Altamira cave art depictions of bison

styleDefinition.origin: Cubism (Paris, c. 1907 - 1914 AD, with later influence)
visualCharacteristics: Revolutionary approach breaking from traditional single-point perspective
Depiction of subjects from multiple viewpoints simultaneously
Fragmentation of objects and figures into geometric facets and overlapping planes
Flattened, shallow, or ambiguous pictorial space; background and foreground often merge
Emphasis on structure and form, especially in Analytical Cubism
Introduction of collage elements (newspaper, wallpaper, etc.) in Synthetic Cubism
Subjects often include still lifes, portraits, and figures
techniques: Oil painting simulation capturing faceted or layered planes
Analysis and geometric reconstruction of form
'Passage' technique where planes blend into one another
Collage / Papier Collé (pasted paper) simulation (Synthetic Cubism)
styleDefinition.mediumSimulation: Oil painting on canvas (potentially incorporating collage elements)

colorPalette.description: Analytical Cubism (c. 1909-12): Severely restricted, near-monochromatic palette focusing on structure (browns, greys, ochres, black, off-white). Synthetic Cubism (c. 1912-14 onwards): Reintroduced brighter, often flat areas of color, sometimes non-naturalistic.
keyColors: (Synthetic): Adds brighter flat Reds, Blues, Greens, Yellows alongside neutrals

styleDefinition.textureEmphasis: Analytical Cubism: Faceted texture created by the interplay of painted planes, often with visible directional brushwork following the facets. Synthetic Cubism: Juxtaposition of flat painted areas with the real or simulated textures of collage elements (paper, wood grain, fabric).
styleDefinition.compositionStyle: Analytical Cubism: Complex, fragmented compositions built from intersecting planes, often dense in the center dissolving towards edges, ambiguous figure-ground relationship. Synthetic Cubism: Simpler, larger, flatter shapes, clearer structure, incorporation of text and collage elements.
references: Pablo Picasso ('Les Demoiselles d'Avignon' - proto, 'Portrait of Ambroise Vollard' - Analytical, 'Still Life with Chair Caning' - Synthetic)
Georges Braque ('Violin and Palette' - Analytical, 'Fruit Dish and Glass' - Synthetic)

sceneContext.lightingStyle: Flat, even, bright lighting with no discernible source or shadows, typical of Egyptian art.
sceneContext.cameraView: Strict profile or composite view, straight-on perspective, avoiding complex angles.
sceneContext.settingSuggestion: A stylized representation of a cave interior or outdoor landscape, framed perhaps with simple geometric Egyptian borders or patterns.

avoid: Dynamic, fluid poses (use stiff Egyptian poses)
